    • Method Detail

      • authenticateBasic

        public static boolean authenticateBasic(javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest request,
                        javax.servlet.http.HttpServletResponse response,
                        String realm,
                        String username,
                        String password)
        Controls access using the basic authentication scheme described in RFC 2617. Note that if running in non-production environment and the given username and password is blank, this method will return true. Typical use looks like: 

         if (!JspUtils.authenticateBasic(request, response, realm, username, password)) {
     return; // Should not send anything else to the response.
 }

      • getAbsolutePath

        public static String getAbsolutePath(javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest request,
                     String path,
                     Object... parameters)
        Returns the absolute version of the given path. The return value includes the context path and is meant for final display (e.g. an HTML page).
        Parameters:
        path - If empty, existing query parameters from the given request are added in addition to the given parameters.
        See Also:
        resolvePath(javax.servlet.ServletContext, javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest, java.lang.String)

      • resolvePath

        public static String resolvePath(javax.servlet.ServletContext context,
                 javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest request,
                 String path)
        Resolves the given path in context of the given request. The return value includes the embedded context path.

        The following list details the different behaviors based on the given path:

        • If null or empty, returns the servlet path.
        • If it starts with /, prefixes the given path with the embedded context path and returns it.
        • If it looks like an absolute URI, returns the given path without any changes.
        • Otherwise, resolves the path in context of the current servlet path and returns it.
        Parameters:
        context - If null, the embedded context path won't be detected. This is only to support legacy APIs, and new applications shouldn't depend on this behavior.
        See Also:
        getAbsolutePath(ServletContext, HttpServletRequest, String, Object...)

      • setAttributes

        public static Map<String,Object> setAttributes(javax.servlet.ServletRequest request,
                               Object... attributes)
        Sets all given attributes in the given request and returns the previously set values.

                                      Map<String,Object> attributes)
        Sets all given attributes in the given request and returns the previously set values.

      • setHeaderResponse

        public static void setHeaderResponse(javax.servlet.ServletRequest request,
                     javax.servlet.ServletResponse response)
        Sets the servlet response that can be used to write the headers on the given request.

        SRV.8.3 in the Java servlet specification states (emphasis added):

        The include method of the RequestDispatcher interface may be called at any time. The target servlet of the include method has access to all aspects of the request object, but its use of the response object is more limited.

        It can only write information to the ServletOutputStream or Writer of the response object and commit a response by writing content past the end of the response buffer, or by explicitly calling the flushBuffer method of the ServletResponse interface. It cannot set headers or call any method that affects the headers of the response. Any attempt to do so must be ignored.

        This method should be used in the parent request so that the included page still has access to set the headers through the parent response object.

        See Also:
        getHeaderResponse(javax.servlet.ServletRequest, javax.servlet.ServletResponse), HeaderResponseFilter

      • setSignedCookie

        IOException
